sentences: Sir Henry Lytton, né Henry Alfred Jones (3 January 1865 – 15 August 1936), was an English actor and singer who was the leading exponent of the comic patter-baritone roles in Gilbert and Sullivan operas from 1909 to 1934.
At the age of 19 he married Louie Henri, an actress and singer who helped him gain a place in a D'Oyly Carte touring company in 1884.
He had an early breakthrough in 1887 when the Savoy Theatre star George Grossmith fell ill, and the 22-year-old Lytton went on for him in Ruddigore.
Lytton starred in D'Oyly Carte touring companies from 1887 to 1897, playing mostly the comic patter roles in the Gilbert and Sullivan (and other) operas.
From 1897 to 1903 he appeared with the company continuously at the Savoy Theatre, playing a range of baritone parts, from romantic leads to character parts in new operas and revivals.

The D'Oyly Carte company left the Savoy Theatre in 1903, and Lytton appeared in half a dozen West End musical comedies over the next four years, including The Earl and the Girl, The Spring Chicken and The Little Michus.
During the two D'Oyly Carte repertory seasons at the Savoy between 1906 and 1909, Lytton rejoined the company, again playing a variety of roles, but mostly not the patter roles.
Beginning in 1909, and continuously to 1934, he was the principal comedian of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in London and on tour.
Beginning in 1909, and continuously to 1934, he was the principal comedian of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in London and on tour.
Lytton was born as Henry Alfred Jones on 3 January 1865 in Pembroke Square, Kensington, London, the son of Henry Jones (1829–1893), a jeweller, and his second wife Martha Lavinia, née Harris.

sentences: Sir Henry Lytton, né Henry Alfred Jones (3 January 1865 – 15 August 1936), was an English actor and singer who was the leading exponent of the comic patter-baritone roles in Gilbert and Sullivan operas from 1909 to 1934.
His career with the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company spanned 50 years, and he is the only person ever knighted for achievements as a Gilbert and Sullivan performer.

The D'Oyly Carte company left the Savoy Theatre in 1903, and Lytton appeared in half a dozen West End musical comedies over the next four years, including The Earl and the Girl, The Spring Chicken and The Little Michus.

sentences: A second investment later in the year, in Melnotte, an operatic version of the comedy The Lady of Lyons, also lost money, after which Lytton abandoned thoughts of being  an impresario.
section: == Life and career == | === The Savoy: 1897 to 1903 ===

sentences: The Savoy closed, reopening the following year under a different management.
section: == Life and career == | === West End: 1903 to 1909 ===

sentences: He starred in The Earl and the Girl and Little Hans Andersen, (1903, alongside Passmore); The Talk of the Town (1905, also with Passmore); The Little Michus (1905, with Evett); The White Chrysanthemum (1905, with Barrington and Jay); The Spring Chicken (1905); and My Darling (1907).
section: == Life and career == | === West End: 1903 to 1909 ===

sentences: He appeared at the Savoy in Helen Carte's first London repertory season of Gilbert and Sullivan in June of that year, playing Strephon.
section: == Life and career == | === West End: 1903 to 1909 ===

sentences: The patter roles were played by C. H. Workman, seconded from the year-round touring company.
section: == Life and career == | === West End: 1903 to 1909 ===

sentences: Although he wrote in 1922 that "the scope and versatility" of Lytton's work was unique, three years earlier, when planning the company's first London season for more than ten years, Carte had hoped to persuade Workman, who was in Australia, to return.
section: == Life and career == | === Principal comedian: 1909 to 1934 ===

sentences: After the opening night of the 1919–20 London season at the Prince's Theatre, in which he played the Duke of Plaza-Toro, The Observer commented:
section: == Life and career == | === Principal comedian: 1909 to 1934 ===

sentences: Lytton starred in three later seasons at the Prince's (1921, 1924 and 1926), in tours of Canada in 1927 and 1928 and the US in 1929, and in London seasons at the Savoy in 1929–30 and 1932–33.
section: == Life and career == | === Principal comedian: 1909 to 1934 ===

sentences: In May the following year Lytton, driving in heavy rain, crashed his car; his passenger, his fellow D'Oyly Carte principal Bertha Lewis, was killed, and he was injured.
section: == Life and career == | === Principal comedian: 1909 to 1934 ===

sentences: He was absent for six weeks, during which Martyn Green, his understudy and eventual successor, took over his roles.
section: == Life and career == | === Principal comedian: 1909 to 1934 ===

sentences: Last years ===
section: == Life and career == | === Last years ===

sentences: After retiring from the D'Oyly Carte company Lytton made his last stage appearance as the Emperor of China in Aladdin, the Christmas pantomime at the Prince of Wales Theatre, Birmingham in 1934–35.
section: == Life and career == | === Last years ===

sentences: In January 1933 the BBC broadcast the last night of the D'Oyly Carte London season, which marked Lytton's last appearance in the West End.
section: == Recordings, film and broadcasts ==

sentences: On Christmas Day of the same year, while the company was playing in the London suburb Golders Green, Lytton – described by the BBC as the "G&S star of stars" – performed in a broadcast of Act 2 of The Mikado from a radio studio in London, with Isidore Godfrey conducting a BBC orchestra and the D'Oyly Carte cast.
